explains: adj. 反抗的；反对的；顽强的
n. 顽抗者；不服从的人

sentences.en: The danger is that recalcitrant local authorities will reject their responsibilities.
sentences.cn: 危险在于那些不服从命令的地方当局将拒绝履行他们的职责。

sentences.en: There was less bullying in secondary schools, with about one in twenty-five suffering persistent bullying, but these cases may be particularly recalcitrant.
sentences.cn: 中学里的霸凌现象较少，约有1/25的学生遭受持续的霸凌，但这些案例可能特别棘手。

sentences.en: It is far more likely that some sort of amicable settlement would be reached if the recalcitrant son or daughter knows that the alternative is a public trial.
sentences.cn: 如果不听话的儿子或女儿知道另一种选择是公开审判，那么更有可能达成某种和解。
